name: CWE-798: Avoid using hardcoded usernames (PeopleSoft)
description:
This metric detects usage of hardcoded usernames and restrictions on how or who should see a page or depending upon the permission list to show different information on the same page.

It detects all tests (If and Evaluate) on %Oprid and %Menu, against hardcoded values.
output:
This report lists all artifacts using hardcoded usernames
It provides the following information:
- PeopleCode artifacts full name
- The associated value is the number violations found in the artifact source code
rationale:
The software should not have hardcoded credentials (username, password) in the application code or files.
Hard-coded credentials typically create a significant security hole that allows an attacker to bypass the authentication that has been configured by the software administrator. This hole might be difficult for the system administrator to detect. 

Harcoded restrictions is also difficult to detect and lower the maintainability of the application.
reference:
PeopleSoft wiki - PeopleTools Security : http://peoplesoft.wikidot.com/peopletools-security
CWE-798: Use of hard-coded credentials : http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/798.html
2011 Top 25 - Porous Defenses : https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/866.html
remediation: Such bespoke behaviors and restrictions should be dealt with via configuration in Peoplesoft rather than hardcoding.

qualityStandards.name: Hard-coded credentials for remote resources
qualityStandards.description: Remove instances where a variable, field, member, etc., is initialized with a hard-coded literal value, and ultimately used to access a remote resource.

qualityStandards.name: Use of Hard-coded Credentials
qualityStandards.description: The software contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.
